comments.body:
It makes sense to add the choices, but I'm concerned that the list can change.  ONTAP may deprecate some choices, or add new choices in a new release.
Here we are only the middle man.  

So if we list all choices, we are helping the end users, but this may become obsolete.
If we don't list the choices, we are to refer the end users to ONTAP documentation.

What's better?

If you can't know valid values to pass the module without consulting external docs that may or may not be accessible to the person developing the content (as IIRC all the useful NetApp docs are behind a paywall that not everyone in the org may have access to), that kinda sucks.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +52,56 @@
  role:
    description:
    - Specifies the role of the LIF.
    - Required when C(state=present).

comments.body:
We don't set a default, as we're picking up whatever ONTAP is using.

I agree this is quite opaque for the end user.

So should we act as a conduit, or be more content aware?

From a user perspective, I'd hope to find one-stop-shopping and that the module would make working with the underlying resource as easy as possible. Again, if figuring out how to use it relies on consulting API developer documentation, I think it's a fail. Your audience likely isn't people who are reading API docs.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +152,156 @@            home_node=dict(required=False, type='str', default=None),
            home_port=dict(required=False, type='str'),

            address=dict(required=False, type='str'),
            netmask=dict(required=False, type='str'),

comments.body: warning on protocol mismatch might not be a bad idea (eg that protocol can't be changed on existing interface)
We'll will improve this in the next release.
